data.title: Central Canada
data.data: More than half of the people in Canada live in Central Canada. Central Canada includes the cities and towns near the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River in southern Quebec and Ontario. It is the industrial and manufacturing heartland. Together, Quebec and Ontario produce more than ¾ of all of Canada’s manufactured goods. Quebec Nearly 8 million people live in Quebec, mostly near the St. Lawrence River. More than 75% speak French as their first language. The important industries are forestry, energy and mining. Quebec is Canada’s main producer of pulp and paper. It is Canada’s largest producer of hydroelectricity because it has so much freshwater. Pharmaceuticals and aeronautics are important industries in Quebec. La Francophonie is an association of French-speaking nations. Montreal is Canada’s second-largest city and the second-largest mainly French-speaking city in the world after Paris. Montreal is famous for its cultural diversity, but Quebec City is Quebec's capital. Ontario Ontario has more than 12 million people. One out of every three Canadians is from Ontario. Toronto is the largest city in Canada and the country’s main financial centre. Many people in Ontario work in the service or manufacturing industries. The Niagara region is known for its vineyards, wines and fruit crops. Ontario farmers raise dairy and beef cattle, poultry, and vegetable and grain crops. Toronto Islands, Ontario, Canada. Ontario was founded by the United Empire Loyalists. It has the largest French-speaking population outside of Quebec and has a proud history of preserving its language and culture. There are five Great Lakes located between Ontario and the United States: Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, Lake Huron, and Lake Michigan. Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake in the world. Hint: You can remember the names of the Great Lakes because they spell the word “HOMES”… Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior.1296,1297,1298,1299,1300,1301,1302,1303,1304,1305,1306,1307,1308

questions.question: More than half of the people in Canada live in Central Canada.
What provinces are located in Central Canada?
questions.feedback: Central Canada includes the cities and towns near the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River in southern Quebec and Ontario.

questions.question: Central Canada known for the industrial and manufacturing heartland.
questions.feedback: Central Canada is the industrial and manufacturing heartland. Together, Quebec and Ontario produce more than 75% of all of Canada's manufactured goods.

questions.question: What language do more than 75% of Quebecois residents speak as their first language?
questions.feedback: More than 75% speak French as their first language in Quebec.

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the important industries in Quebec?
questions.feedback: The important industries are forestry, energy and mining in Quebec.

questions.question: What is Quebec's capital city?
questions.feedback: Montreal is famous for its cultural diversity, but Quebec City is Quebec's capital.

questions.question: What is the world's second largest French-speaking city?
questions.feedback: Montreal is Canada's second-largest city and the second-largest mainly French-speaking city in the world after Paris.

questions.question: How many people live in Ontario?
questions.feedback: Ontario has more than 12 million people

questions.question: More people live in Quebec than Ontario.
questions.feedback: Ontario has more than 12 million people, on the other hand, Quebec has a population of nearly 8 million people.

questions.question: What is the largest city in Canada?
questions.feedback: Toronto is the largest city in Canada. It is also Canada's financial centre.

questions.question: Who founded Ontario?
questions.feedback: Ontario was founded by the United Empire Loyalists.

questions.question: There are five Great Lakes located between Ontario and the United States.
questions.feedback: There are five Great Lakes located between Ontario and the United States: Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan and Lake Superior.

questions.question: Which of the Great Lakes is the largest freshwater lake in the world?
questions.feedback: Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake in the world.

data.title: The Prairie Provinces
data.data: Manitoba Manitoba’s economy is based on agriculture, mining and hydro-electric power generation. Winnipeg is the capital of Manitoba, and it has the largest population of all the cities in Manitoba. The Exchange District in Winnipeg has the most famous street intersection in Canada, Portage and Main. St. Boniface, in Winnipeg’s French quarter, has the largest Francophone community. It has 45,000 people. Manitoba is an important centre of Ukrainian culture, with 14% of Manitobans having Ukrainian ancestors. Manitoba has the largest Aboriginal population of any province. The Aboriginal population is over 15%. The Forks, Winnipeg, MB, Canada. By Brydon McCluskey. Saskatchewan Saskatchewan was once known as the breadbasket of the world and the wheat province. It has over 40% of the arable land (land that is good for growing crops) in Canada. It is Canada’s largest producer of grains and oilseeds. It has uranium and potash. Potash is used in fertilizer. Saskatchewan produces oil and natural gas. Regina is the capital of Saskatchewan. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has a training academy in Saskatchewan. Saskatoon is the largest city. Indian Head, Saskatchewan, Canada. By Dan Loran. Alberta Alberta is the Prairie province that has the most people. The province got its name from the fourth daughter of Queen Victoria; Princess Louise Caroline Alberta. The world-famous Lake Louise in the Rocky Mountains was also named after her. Alberta has five national parks. Banff National Park was established in 1885. Alberta also has the Badlands. A badland is a type of land which is very dry, and where the soft rock has been eroded (washed or blown away) by wind and/or water for a long period of time. There are prehistoric fossils and the remains of dinosaurs in Alberta. Alberta is the largest producer of oil and gas. The oil sands in northern Alberta are a major energy source. Alberta is also known for its agriculture, especially cattle ranches. Canada is one of the world’s major beef producers. Moraine Lake, Banff, Alberta, Canada. By Andy Holmes.1309,1310,1311,1312,1313,1314,1315,1316,1317,1318

questions.question: What is the capital of Manitoba?
questions.feedback: Winnipeg is the capital of Manitoba, and it has the largest population of all the cities in Manitoba.

questions.question: What cultures or communities does Manitoba have?
questions.feedback: St. Boniface in Winnipeg's has the largest Francophone community. Also, 14% of Manitobans having Ukrainian ancestors.

questions.question: Manitoba has the largest Aboriginal population of any province.
questions.feedback: With over 15% of the population being Aboriginal,  Manitoba has the largest Aboriginal population of any province.

questions.question: Saskatchewan was known as the breadbasket of the world, or the wheat province.
questions.feedback: Saskatchewan was once known as the breadbasket of the world and the wheat province. It has over 40% of the arable land (land that is good for growing crops) in Canada.

questions.question: What is the capital of Saskatchewan?
questions.feedback: Regina is the capital of Saskatchewan.

questions.question: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has a training academy in Alberta.
questions.feedback: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has a training academy in Saskatchewan.

questions.question: Which province has the largest population in the Prairies?
questions.feedback: Alberta is the Prairie province which has the most people.

questions.question: Where did Alberta get it's name?
questions.feedback: The province got its name from the fourth daughter of Queen Victoria; Princess Louise Caroline Alberta.
options: 1 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of Queen Victoria
2 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II
3 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of King George V
4 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of King Charles I

questions.question: Which one is one of Alberta's national parks?
Alberta is the largest producer of oil and gas in Canada.

data.title: The West Coast
data.data: British Columbia (BC) is known for its mountains and as the Pacific Gateway (entry to the Pacific Ocean area). The Port of Vancouver is Canada’s largest and busiest port. British Columbia is on the west side of Canada. It has a population of four million. Downtown Vancouver, Canada. Half of all the goods produced in BC are forestry products, including lumber, newsprint, and pulp and paper products. BC has the most valuable forestry industry in Canada. BC is also known for mining, fishing, and the fruit orchards and wine industry of the Okanagan Valley. BC has the most parks in Canada, about 600 provincial parks. BC also has large Asian communities, and Chinese and Punjabi are the most spoken languages in the cities, after English. The capital of BC is Victoria. Earls Cove, British Columbia, Canada.1319,1320,1321,1322

questions.question: What is Canada's largest and busiest port?
questions.feedback: The Port of Vancouver is Canada's largest and busiest port

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest industry?
questions.feedback: Half of all the goods produced in BC are forestry products, including lumber, newsprint, and pulp and paper products.

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest ethnic community?
questions.feedback: BC has large Asian communities, and Chinese and Punjabi are the most-spoken languages in the cities, after English.

questions.question: What is the capital city of British Columbia?
questions.feedback: The capital of BC is Victoria.

data.title: The North I
data.data: The Northwest Territories, Nunavut and Yukon contain one third of Canada’s land mass, but they have a very small population of only 100,000 people. There are gold, lead, copper, diamond and zinc mines. Oil and gas deposits are being developed. The North is sometimes called the Land of the Midnight Sun because, in the middle of summer, daylight can last up to 24 hours. In the winter the sun disappears, and darkness lasts for three months. Yukon, Canada. Most of the North is made up of tundra, which is an area between the icecap and the tree line of Arctic regions. Tundra has frozen soil under the top layer, and no trees. Because of the cold Arctic climate, there are no trees on the tundra, and the soil is permanently frozen. There is still hunting, fishing and trapping of animals. Inuit art is sold throughout Canada and around the world. The Canadian Rangers The Canadian Forces Reserves (militia) are called the Canadian Rangers. They travel by snowmobile in the winter and all-terrain vehicles in the summer. They help to protect the Arctic.1323,1324,1325

questions.question: The North is also called The Land of the Midnight Sun, because in the summer daylight can last up to 24 hours.
questions.feedback: The North is sometimes called the Land of the Midnight Sun because, in the middle of summer, daylight can last up to 24 hours.

questions.question: How much of Canada's land mass does the North take up?
questions.feedback: The Northwest Territories, Nunavut, and Yukon contain one-third of Canada's landmass.

questions.question: What kind of art is made in the North and sold in Canada and around the world?
questions.feedback: Inuit art is sold throughout Canada and around the world.

data.title: The North II
data.data: Yukon In the 1890s, during the Gold Rush, thousands of miners came to the Yukon Territory. The Gold Rush is the name for the time in which many people hurried (rushed) to go north to try to get rich from the gold in the Yukon. Robert W. Service is a poet who wrote about this. Mining is an important part of the economy. In 1900, the railway called The White Pass and Yukon Railway opened from Skagway (in Alaska, which is an American state beside Yukon) to Whitehorse. Whitehorse is the capital of Yukon. Many tourists like to take this railway. Yukon Territory, Canada. Photo: Kalen Emsley. Yukon has the coldest temperature ever recorded in Canada (-63 degrees C). Mount Logan is located in the Yukon. It is the highest mountain in Canada. It is named after Sir William Logan. He was a world-famous Canadian geologist. He founded and directed the Geological Survey of Canada from 1842 to 1869. The Northwest Territories The Northwest Territories were originally made up in 1870, using land from Rupert’s land. Rupert’s land was land that drained into the Hudson’s Bay, and which the Hudson's Bay Company used for 200 years from 1670 to 1870. The capital of the Northwest Territories is Yellowknife. It has a population of 20,000 and is called the diamond capital of North America. Mackenzie River, Northwest Territories, Canada. Photo: Alan Emery. More than half of the population in the Northwest Territories is Aboriginal (Dene, Inuit, Métis). The Mackenzie River is the second-longest river system in North America. (The Mississippi River in the US is longer.) Nunavut Nunavut means our land in Inuktitut. It was established in 1999. The capital is Iqaluit, which used to be called Frobisher Bay. Frobisher Bay was named after the English explorer Martin Frobisher, who went into the Arctic in 1576. Pangnirtung Fijord, Nunavut, Canada. Photo: Isaac Demeester. Nunavut has 19 members in its Legislative Assembly. They choose a premier and ministers by consensus. The population is about 85% Inuit. Inuktitut is an official language and the first language in schools.1326,1327,1328,1329,1330,1331,1332,1333,1334,1335,1336

questions.question: What happened in the 1890s in the Yukon territory?
questions.feedback: In the 1890s, during the Gold Rush, thousands of miners came to the Yukon Territory for gold.

questions.question: What is the highest mountain in Canada?
questions.feedback: Mount Logan is located in the Yukon. It is the highest mountain in Canada.

questions.question: What is the capital city of the Yukon territory?
questions.feedback: Whitehorse is the capital of Yukon.

questions.question: What is an important part of Yukon's economy?
questions.feedback: Mining is an important part of the economy of Yukon.

questions.question: The Northwest Territories were originally made up in 1870, using land from Rupert's land.
What is the capital of the Northwest Territories?
questions.feedback: The capital of the Northwest Territories is Yellowknife.

questions.question: Yellowknife is called the diamond capital of North America.
What group makes up more than half of the population of Northwest Territories?
questions.feedback: More than half of the population in the Northwest Territories are Aboriginal (Dene, Inuit, Métis).

questions.question: Nunavut means "our land" in Inuktitut.
questions.feedback: Nunavut means our land in Inuktitut.

questions.question: What is the capital of Nunavut?
questions.feedback: The capital is Iqaluit, which used to be called Frobisher Bay.

questions.question: What percentage of the Nunavut population is Inuit?
questions.feedback: The Nunavut population is about 85% Inuit.
